title: Global ambitions, African focus: Suneet Singal's quest to transform renewable energy markets
description:
You can’t rely on one or two technologies and expect to solve global energy demand.
Singal’s portfolio includes renewable energy initiatives tied to Ukraine’s post-war reconstruction, helping to rebuild energy independence through decentralized generation and smart-grid technologies.
Technologically, the mix of methanol-to-jet fuel, gasification, and eSAF represents a pragmatic evolution of renewable energy, one that integrates circular-economy principles.
Such integration could also help stabilize energy markets in regions where volatility has been the norm.
In Africa, for instance, renewable infrastructure tied to local employment and capacity-building creates a buffer against political instability.
text:
Where others see fragmented markets and regulatory complexity, Singal sees opportunity. His strategy involves both technological and geographical diversification. In doing so, this creates a network of renewable assets tailored to the resources and realities of each region. While much of the industry remains fixated on solar, wind, and hydrogen, Singal is pivoting toward more commercially resilient and politically viable alternatives, including methanol and methanol-to-jet fuels via gasification, eSAF (electrically powered sustainable aviation fuel) plants, HEFA-based SAF, and renewable diesel, as well as nuclear power. These are being coupled with digital infrastructure projects such as energy-efficient data centers and blockchain-based tokenization to enhance transparency and liquidity across the global energy trade.

“Governments and corporations are rethinking how they approach renewables. You can’t rely on one or two technologies and expect to solve global energy demand. What we’re building is a framework that works across geographies and is scalable, flexible, and financially sustainable.” Explained Singal.

That framework is already taking shape. Singal’s portfolio includes renewable energy initiatives tied to Ukraine’s post-war reconstruction, helping to rebuild energy independence through decentralized generation and smart-grid technologies. In Kazakhstan, Bulgaria, and Azerbaijan, his teams are working with local partners to introduce next-generation fuels that support industrial decarbonization and reduce reliance on imported hydrocarbons. In the Middle East, projects in Dubai and Qatar complement government-led diversification programs by offering scalable, private-sector solutions. Meanwhile, in the United States, development is advancing in Texas, Louisiana, and California; the latter of which is home to a fire-forest feedstock gasification plant that converts forest waste into clean energy, transforming an environmental hazard into a valuable resource.

ADVERTISEMENT

Each initiative is designed to operate independently yet contribute to a unified global ecosystem. Financing structures often tie into export-import frameworks, enabling projects to move capital efficiently between regions. The inclusion of tokenization models that digitize project assets and energy credits aims to make the traditionally slow-moving energy sector more transparent and accessible to global investors.

Africa remains a cornerstone of this strategy. Long seen as the next frontier for renewables, the continent’s potential is finally aligning with investor interest. There has already been large-scale HEFA-based SAF and renewable diesel production in Ethiopia and South Africa. In Ethiopia, local feedstocks such as castor oil and Ethiopian mustard are being explored for conversion into sustainable fuels. At the same time, South Africa’s existing Fischer-Tropsch infrastructure provides an ideal foundation for processing related feedstocks. The Congo, meanwhile, represents a region where renewable projects could deliver both immediate and long-term benefits, from job creation to regional stability.

“The key is localization. Africa has the resources and the talent. What it needs are frameworks that connect local potential with global markets, and that’s what we’re helping to create.” Says Singal.

This approach reflects a growing recognition that the energy transition cannot rely solely on public funding or top-down policy. Many governments, particularly in emerging markets, lack the infrastructure or capital to scale renewables at the necessary pace. By introducing private investment backed by export-import financing and international partnerships, Singal’s model bridges the gap between national ambition and financial reality.

Technologically, the mix of methanol-to-jet fuel, gasification, and eSAF represents a pragmatic evolution of renewable energy, one that integrates circular-economy principles. Methanol-to-jet fuels and HEFA pathways utilize waste biomass and oils, reducing lifecycle emissions while providing a stable, energy-dense alternative to fossil fuels. Nuclear power, often overlooked in short-term political cycles, offers baseload stability critical to balancing intermittent renewables. Together, they form a hybrid energy architecture capable of supporting everything from regional grids to digital infrastructure like data centers, which are increasingly energy-intensive.

ADVERTISEMENT

“This isn’t just about replacing fossil fuels. It’s about designing an entire ecosystem that works technically, financially, and environmentally. That means integrating generation, financing, and technology under one umbrella.” Added Singal.

Such integration could also help stabilize energy markets in regions where volatility has been the norm. In Africa, for instance, renewable infrastructure tied to local employment and capacity-building creates a buffer against political instability. In Eastern Europe, decentralized grids and hybrid systems can protect national energy supplies from disruption. And in the U.S., a new generation of decentralized projects could make clean power more resilient to natural disasters and grid congestion.

Beyond the technical elements, Singal’s initiatives carry broader geopolitical significance. Energy has always been a tool of influence, so by establishing renewable and nuclear projects that link continents, private investors are increasingly shaping the future of global power, both literally and figuratively.

“If we’re going to hit Net-Zero targets, we need collaboration, not competition between regions. HEFA-based SAF, renewable diesel, methanol, and eSAF can all play a part. Kenya Airways recently flew a 50% locally sourced SAF blend, so that’s proof it can be done. The challenge now is scaling that success across continents.” Concluded SIngal.

From Africa’s renewable corridors to the industrial hubs of Eastern Europe, Singal’s global portfolio illustrates the next phase of the energy transition. It is no longer defined by single technologies, but by systems thinking. It’s a model where private capital, public policy, and innovation align. It’s also a model where the future of energy is being rewritten, one region at a time.

title: The Soaring Future of Europe's Aviation Market - Vocal Media
description:
Rising Air Travel Demand One of the most influential forces behind Europe’s aviation expansion is the rising demand for air travel.
Growing Air Cargo and E-Commerce Activity Europe’s aviation sector is witnessing an unprecedented rise in air cargo operations.
Intense Market Competition Europe’s aviation market is highly competitive, with full-service airlines, regional carriers, and low-cost operators competing across domestic and international routes.
Recent Developments in Europe’s Aviation Market January 2025 – Airbus Helicopters Airbus delivered two H225M helicopters to France’s Armament General Directorate (DGA), part of an eight-unit order.
The Boeing Company Dassault Aviation Leonardo S.p.A Final Thoughts Europe’s aviation sector is poised for a decade of steady and strategic growth.
text:
The Europe Aviation Market is entering one of its most transformative decades. According to Renub Research, the Europe Aviation Market is expected to reach US$ 88.17 billion by 2033, rising from US$ 57.47 billion in 2024, and registering a CAGR of 4.87% from 2025 to 2033. This growth reflects a strong rebound from the pandemic years, driven by surging travel demand, modernization of fleets, technological innovations, and expanding cargo activity influenced by booming e-commerce.

Aviation is not just a mode of transportation—it is a high-impact economic engine that propels tourism, global trade, business mobility, and social connectivity. Europe, with its dense travel corridors, advanced airport infrastructure, and strong regulatory frameworks, remains one of the world’s most important aviation hubs.

Request Free Sample Report

Europe Aviation Industry Overview

Aviation in Europe spans the entire ecosystem of aircraft design, manufacturing, airline operations, airport services, maintenance, and air traffic management. With world-leading manufacturers like Airbus, robust airport networks in cities such as Paris, Frankfurt, and Amsterdam, and a diverse mix of full-service and low-cost carriers, Europe retains a significant share of the global aviation landscape.

The industry’s operations include:

Commercial passenger flights

Cargo and freight transportation

Private and business aviation

Military aircraft operations

Maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO)

Airport and ground handling services

Modern aviation relies heavily on fuel-efficient aircraft, cutting-edge navigation technologies, digital check-in processes, and AI-enabled air traffic systems. By enabling fast, long-distance travel and facilitating trade, aviation continues to serve as a backbone for Europe’s economy, supporting millions of jobs and enabling cross-border movement.

In recent years, the sector’s growth has been fueled by:

Rising disposable incomes

Tourism recovery

Expansion of low-cost carriers

Enhanced airport capacity

Technological advancements such as sustainable aviation fuel (SAF)

Strong demand for freight and e-commerce shipments

Key Growth Drivers for the Europe Aviation Market

1. Rising Air Travel Demand

One of the most influential forces behind Europe’s aviation expansion is the rising demand for air travel. Increasing disposable incomes, fast-paced urbanization, and the need for cross-border mobility all contribute to growing passenger volumes.

Post-pandemic trends show that European travelers prefer quick, safe, and convenient transportation, boosting airline revenues. Airlines are launching new routes, enhancing flight schedules, and investing in modern fleets to meet this surge in demand.

The growth of low-cost carriers, offering affordable travel options, further fuels this shift. Additionally, flexible booking policies and promotional fare structures encourage more people to fly frequently for holidays, reunions, and short business trips.

This growing passenger base ensures:

Higher aircraft utilization

Strong airline profitability

Long-term stability for Europe’s aviation marketplace

2. Business and Leisure Tourism Expansion

Europe remains one of the world’s most visited destinations. From the Eiffel Tower to the Colosseum to the beaches of Spain and Greece, the continent attracts millions of tourists annually.

At the same time, Europe is a global hub for international business events, conferences, exhibitions, and corporate travel. Cities like Frankfurt, London, Paris, and Milan host major trade fairs and industry gatherings, leading to sustained demand for business flights.

Airlines are responding by:

Adding premium services for business travelers

Offering bundled travel packages

Expanding networks to high-demand tourist regions

Enhancing loyalty programs

Airport expansions, better terminal facilities, and improved local connectivity further elevate Europe’s tourism-driven flight volumes.

3. Growing Air Cargo and E-Commerce Activity

Europe’s aviation sector is witnessing an unprecedented rise in air cargo operations. The rapid expansion of e-commerce platforms—powered by the demand for fast, efficient delivery—has significantly boosted freight volumes.

Air cargo now plays a major role in transporting:

Pharmaceuticals

Electronics

Fashion

Perishable foods

High-value industrial components

To meet this demand, airlines are expanding their freighter fleet, optimizing cargo routes, and investing in advanced logistics technologies, including real-time cargo tracking and automated warehouses.

Partnerships between airlines, logistics operators, and e-commerce platforms (such as Amazon and DHL) continue to strengthen Europe’s air cargo ecosystem, offering new revenue channels beyond passenger travel.

Challenges in the Europe Aviation Market

1. Rising Fuel Costs

Fuel remains one of the largest cost components for airlines. Volatile global oil prices directly impact operational margins. Short-haul carriers are particularly affected due to their frequent takeoff and landing cycles, which consume more fuel.

Airlines are countering this through:

Fleet modernization

Exploring sustainable aviation fuels (SAF)

Optimizing flight paths

Implementing AI-driven fuel management

Despite these measures, persistently high fuel prices pose long-term risks to profitability.

2. Intense Market Competition

Europe’s aviation market is highly competitive, with full-service airlines, regional carriers, and low-cost operators competing across domestic and international routes.

This leads to:

Price wars

Lower ticket fares

Pressure on profit margins

Major airline alliances, code-sharing agreements, and strategic mergers heighten competition and influence smaller carriers’ survival prospects. To differentiate, airlines invest in:

Digital enhancements

Loyalty programs

Onboard comforts

Flexible ticketing policies

Competition will remain a defining challenge as the market grows.

Country-Level Analysis

France

France boasts one of Europe’s most dynamic aviation markets. Major airports such as Charles de Gaulle, Orly, Nice, and Lyon handle massive volumes of passenger and cargo traffic annually. Strong tourism, cultural attractions, and business travel demand bolster its aviation sector.

Technological modernization, green aviation initiatives, and digital improvements such as automated check-ins further support efficiency. Challenges include strict environmental regulations and the high cost of compliance, but France’s strategic positioning and robust tourism industry ensure long-term growth.

Germany

Germany, Europe’s largest economy, plays a central role in aviation. Major hubs like Frankfurt, Munich, and Berlin connect Europe with Asia, North America, and the Middle East.

Germany benefits from:

Strong business travel

High-income consumers

Expanding e-commerce cargo activity

Continuous airport upgrades

While environmental restrictions and fuel costs remain concerns, Germany’s commitment to digital transformation and aircraft modernization keeps it at the forefront of the European aviation landscape.

Italy

Italy’s aviation sector thrives on its world-famous tourism industry, connecting millions of travelers to cities like Rome, Milan, Florence, and Venice. The Mediterranean country is a major gateway between Europe, Africa, and the Middle East.

Italy continues to expand its aviation infrastructure, improve passenger services, and invest in cargo capacity. Despite competitive pressures and operational challenges, Italy remains a strong contributor to Europe’s aviation ecosystem.

Spain

Spain hosts some of Europe’s busiest airports, including Madrid, Barcelona, and Palma de Mallorca. A tourism powerhouse, Spain welcomes millions of travelers each year for leisure, holidays, and business events.

Low-cost carriers dominate the domestic and regional flight landscape, stimulating mobility and economic activity. Spain is also investing heavily in airport digitalization, sustainability, and cargo logistics. Despite seasonal fluctuations and regulatory hurdles, Spain’s aviation market is poised for continued expansion.

Recent Developments in Europe’s Aviation Market

January 2025 – Airbus Helicopters

Airbus delivered two H225M helicopters to France’s Armament General Directorate (DGA), part of an eight-unit order. These aircraft will support the modernization of France’s Air and Space Force, contributing to defense, search and rescue, and utility missions.

January 2025 – Babcock International Group PLC

Babcock secured a 17-year contract to supply 22 Pilatus PC-7 MKX trainer aircraft to the French armed forces under the Mentor2 program. This strengthens France’s military pilot training capabilities across both the Air Force and Navy.

Europe Aviation Market Segmentation

By Revenue Stream

Passenger

Freight

By Type

Commercial Aircraft

Military Aircraft

General Aircraft

By Component

Aircraft

MRO (Maintenance, Repair & Overhaul)

Ground Handling Services

By Country

France, Germany, Italy, Spain, United Kingdom, Belgium, Netherlands, Russia, Poland, Greece, Norway, Romania, Portugal, Rest of Europe

Key Companies Covered

Each company is analyzed from:

✔ Company Overview

✔ Key Persons

✔ Recent Developments & Strategies

✔ SWOT Analysis

✔ Sales Analysis

Major players include:

Lockheed Martin Corporation

Airbus SE

Saab AB

Bombardier Inc.

Textron Inc.

Pilatus Aircraft Ltd.

The Boeing Company

Dassault Aviation

Leonardo S.p.A

Final Thoughts

Europe’s aviation sector is poised for a decade of steady and strategic growth. With increasing travel demand, rising cargo volumes, and strong infrastructure expansion, the market’s fundamentals remain solid. While challenges such as fuel price volatility and competition persist, continued investments in digitalization, sustainability, and fleet modernization will help Europe maintain its global aviation leadership.

By 2033, Europe’s aviation market is not only expected to reach US$ 88.17 billion, but also become more efficient, sustainable, and technologically advanced, offering a more seamless and safer travel experience for millions.

title: Four projects win 5 million yuan at green future innovation challenge 2025 in Shenzhen
description:
Four cutting-edge projects were declared winners at the Grand Finale of the Green Future Innovation Challenge (GFIC) 2025 held in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, sharing a prize pool of 5 million yuan ($70.6 million), reports Chinadaily.com.cn.
Feynman Dynamics won the top honour, receiving the Outstanding Award along with 2 million yuan.
The remaining 3 million yuan was shared by ROTBOOST and two Shenzhen-based companies — Daotong New Energy and ZH Energy.
It drew more than 1,000 high-quality green technology solutions from over 70 countries and regions.
She praised China’s leadership in the global green transition and stressed the importance of cross-border and cross-sector collaboration to advance scalable sustainable development solutions in response to climate challenges.
text:
Four cutting-edge projects were declared winners at the Grand Finale of the Green Future Innovation Challenge (GFIC) 2025 held in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, sharing a prize pool of 5 million yuan ($70.6 million), reports Chinadaily.com.cn.

The inaugural competition, co-hosted by Vertex Ventures China and Temasek Foundation, aims to identify and support technological innovations that are commercially viable and aligned with global sustainability goals.

Feynman Dynamics won the top honour, receiving the Outstanding Award along with 2 million yuan. The remaining 3 million yuan was shared by ROTBOOST and two Shenzhen-based companies — Daotong New Energy and ZH Energy.

Feynman Dynamics, a deep-tech startup, has developed technology for large-scale, cost-effective electrochemical production of sustainable aviation fuel capable of reducing life-cycle emissions by more than 90% compared to conventional jet fuel.

ROTBOOST will work with Baowu Group, the world’s largest steelmaker, on a pilot project to demonstrate thermal catalytic decomposition of methane to help cut emissions in the steel and aluminium sectors.

Daotong New Energy has created a technology that fully recycles retired lithium iron phosphate batteries, recovering high-value materials. ZH Energy has developed advanced iron-sulfur battery technology that can replace vanadium and lithium batteries, offering a safer and more affordable option for integrating renewable energy into the power grid.

Organisers said the competition focused on industrial decarbonisation, energy transition, green agriculture, and pollution reduction. It drew more than 1,000 high-quality green technology solutions from over 70 countries and regions.

After several evaluation rounds, 30 projects reached the semifinals, and 10 were shortlisted for the final.

Singapore’s Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs and Home Affairs, Sim Ann, attended the event on Monday, calling it a testament to the longstanding cooperation between Singapore and China. She praised China’s leadership in the global green transition and stressed the importance of cross-border and cross-sector collaboration to advance scalable sustainable development solutions in response to climate challenges.

title: One year into his 2nd term, Houston has lived up to many campaign promises, but he's ... - CBC
description:
The platform suggested the government would put its heft into making life more affordable, with attention also going to housing and health care.
A couple months after the election, Houston started talking more explicitly about his vision for natural resource development, and a flurry of government action ensued.
The province needs a stronger economy, his refrain goes, to pay for things like schools, housing and health care.
Has health care been sidelined?
Katherine Fierlbeck, the McCulloch professor of political science at Dalhousie University, gives the PC government ongoing credit for its commitment to health care in its first term.
text:
In the 12 months since the Houston government won its second mandate, it’s made progress or fully delivered on many of the promises made during last fall’s election campaign.

The platform suggested the government would put its heft into making life more affordable, with attention also going to housing and health care. It gave nods to soaring rates of violence in schools and gridlock traffic in the capital region.

The Progressive Conservative government has indeed followed through, to varying degrees, with promises related to all those issues. But the focus of the government’s second term has been on natural resource development, which was given only a vague reference in the campaign platform.

First, what’s been delivered. In spring 2025 Nova Scotia saw a one-point cut to provincial sales tax, an increase to the basic personal amount for income tax and a one-point cut to the small business tax rate.

Tax cuts might be popular among voters, but the resulting revenue losses are probably to the chagrin of the Finance Department, which is now grappling with a $1.2-billion deficit. As it works on next year’s budget, the department has already directed departments to slow down hiring and explore some potential cuts.

The PC government also delivered free shingles vaccines for people 65 and older, a two-step increase to the minimum wage (bringing it to $16.50 this fall), and did away with bridge tolls and parking fees for hospital patients and visitors.

Another checkmark goes beside the promise to make more vacant public land available for affordable housing, though it’s a case that shows a promise kept doesn’t always equate to instant gratification or impact.

Yes, the PCs offered up two new pieces of land in the past year. No, there aren’t any new housing units to show for it. The land-for-housing program started in 2021 and land added in the government’s first term has so far resulted in a total of 18 new units, with nine of them renting below market rates.

For people now living in those units, the program likely seems worthwhile, but overall it would be hard to call it a runaway success. And given how acutely some people are still feeling the housing crisis, some might have expected more from the PC platform on housing.

The only other housing promise was to help first-time homebuyers to make a smaller down payment. That hasn't yet happened, although the province says "news will be coming very soon" about the program.

Another pledge that received mixed reviews was free hospital parking. While it wouldn't be a problem in smaller communities, in Halifax it underscored a shortage of parking spaces around hospitals and spurred staff complaints about being squeezed out of lots and parkades at their workplaces.

Other promises show signs of progress, or the government at least says it intends to follow through. See the full list below.

The PCs are, after all, just one year into a mandate that could last as long as four, so they still have time to make good on all their pledges, even if there’s no sign of movement yet.

The big pivot

One section of the election platform talks about strengthening the economy through natural resource development, but it didn’t garner much attention during the campaign. That’s probably partly because the party didn’t give it the platform of a stand-alone announcement — as it did with items such as a menopause centre of excellence and nixing bridge tolls — and partly because there were no concrete promises.

“We will realize the potential of our natural resources to produce the energy of tomorrow,” one campaign document said. “We are focusing on building the economy for the long term by taking advantage of our natural resources.”

Campaign materials referred to the province’s critical mineral potential, and the possibility of kick-starting local hydrogen and sustainable aviation fuel industries.

Premier Tim Houston has said it wasn’t yet apparent at campaign time how necessary the push for resource development would be. But a year on, it’s now clear this work is the fulcrum of this mandate.

A couple months after the election, Houston started talking more explicitly about his vision for natural resource development, and a flurry of government action ensued.

The government lifted restrictions on fracking and uranium exploration and mining, streamlined environmental assessment and industrial permitting processes, opened a new call for offshore oil and gas exploration, and crafted an ambitious plan for offshore wind development — the list goes on.

Many of those actions have faced significant pushback over fears about environmental protection and human health, but Houston has been insistent that anything pursued will be done safely. It’s necessary, he says, to find new revenue streams as population growth and the economic boom of the past few years slows.

The province needs a stronger economy, his refrain goes, to pay for things like schools, housing and health care.

Has health care been sidelined?

The issue that helped drive the Tories into government in the first place may appear to have taken a back seat this time around. Health-related promises are fewer than they were in 2021, and even among the new promises, one is not directly related to health care (free parking) and another is already behind schedule (legislation for independent evaluations of the health authority was supposed to be tabled by earlier this year).

But sitting in the back seat isn’t the same as stopping or being left behind.

Katherine Fierlbeck, the McCulloch professor of political science at Dalhousie University, gives the PC government ongoing credit for its commitment to health care in its first term.

“It takes some time to be able to see the net effect of whether this is going to work well or not,” she said.

Fierlbeck, who studies health policy, said meaningful change in health care requires governments to “pump the money in,” which could be more challenging to do in the face of a sizable deficit and a contraction of money coming in. But momentum could carry the system forward for some time, she added.

How long things can coast before the big bet on natural resources will have to prove its worth — that might be a subject for the next election.

title: Airbus' Bid to Make Aviation Manufacturing more Sustainable
description:
Within this landscape, Airbus is designing its aircraft with the aim of helping to transition the industry towards more sustainable practices.
In fact, our sister title Sustainability Magazine recently ranked Airbus 48th in its Top 250 World’s Most Sustainable Companies 2025.
Airbus' sustainability targets Airbus has established sustainability targets that have been validated by the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) as outlined in its 2025 Pioneering Sustainable Aviation report.
He adds: “Airbus is advocating for and investing in sustainable aviation fuels, which are critical to making progress in reducing emissions today.
Airbus is focused on increasing the adoption of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) throughout the sector.
text:
The aviation industry is a major contributor to economic growth and global connectivity. According to the Air Transport Action Group, the sector contributed US$4.1tn to global GDP and supported 86.5 million jobs in 2023.

Within this landscape, Airbus is designing its aircraft with the aim of helping to transition the industry towards more sustainable practices.

In fact, our sister title Sustainability Magazine recently ranked Airbus 48th in its Top 250 World’s Most Sustainable Companies 2025.

Airbus' sustainability targets

Airbus has established sustainability targets that have been validated by the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) as outlined in its 2025 Pioneering Sustainable Aviation report.

Goals include a 63% reduction in its Scope 1 and 2 absolute greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and the neutralisation of any residual emissions. Furthermore, Airbus aims to decrease its Scope 3 greenhouse gas emissions intensity by 46% by 2035, using 2015 as a baseline year.

Safety remains a primary focus in its operations for its employees, products and services. Airbus's aircraft, helicopters and satellites are built to meet stringent regulatory standards with safety integrated into the design, testing and production phases.

Airbus is actively contributing to the wider aerospace industry's long-term objective of achieving net zero emissions by 2050.

Guillaume Faury, CEO at Airbus, says: “This means expanding production of these new, fuel-efficient aircraft to help airlines accelerate the renewal of their fleets.

He adds: “Airbus is advocating for and investing in sustainable aviation fuels, which are critical to making progress in reducing emissions today. Our core principles of safety, quality, integrity, compliance and security will guide us in all we do.”

Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and the energy transition

A key component of Airbus's strategy is its decarbonisation roadmap, designed to support the energy transition in aviation. Airbus is focused on increasing the adoption of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) throughout the sector.

Currently, its aircraft can operate on a blend of up to 50% SAF and conventional fuel. Airbus has set a target for all its aircraft and helicopters to be capable of flying with 100% SAF by 2030.

The use of SAF could lead to a potential reduction in carbon dioxide equivalent emissions of up to 80% over its lifecycle compared to conventional kerosene, according to the International Civil Aviation Organisation.

To advance this goal, Airbus is collaborating with fuel producers, airlines, governments and researchers to accelerate SAF production and improve its availability on a global scale.

A circular economy approach to aircraft manufacturing

Airbus incorporates a lifecycle approach in its manufacturing process, designing its products for longevity with a lifespan intended to exceed 20 years. Airbus seeks to minimise environmental impacts across its operations and supply chains.

It has been working on enhancing supply chain resilience from the sourcing of materials through to the end-of-life management of its products.

A primary objective for Airbus is to reduce waste and the consumption of raw materials, thereby extending the lifespan of its services and products. Airbus also encourages its customers and partners to adopt similar circular economy principles.

Specific targets include a 20% reduction in waste collection and achieving 0% landfilling and incineration without energy recovery by 2030 compared to 2015 levels.

Julie Kitcher, Chief Sustainability Officer at Airbus, says: “We want to do business in a way that benefits society as a whole.”

title: The Gulf's Energy Focus Is Transforming Airport Infrastructure Into Power Stations
description:
Walk across the tarmac at Red Sea International Airport and the energy story looks nothing like a traditional Gulf hub.
The terminal and airfield run on power generated by more than 760,000 solar panels, supported by one of the world’s largest off-grid battery systems.
Red Sea Global, the airport’s developer, has said the airport “will be powered using renewable energy alone,” part of its plan for the entire destination to operate on 100% renewable electricity.
Pilot projects and operating models Most Gulf airports are still early in the journey.
Red Sea International shows what a fully renewable airport can look like.
text:
Walk across the tarmac at Red Sea International Airport and the energy story looks nothing like a traditional Gulf hub.

The terminal and airfield run on power generated by more than 760,000 solar panels, supported by one of the world’s largest off-grid battery systems.

Red Sea Global, the airport’s developer, has said the airport “will be powered using renewable energy alone,” part of its plan for the entire destination to operate on 100% renewable electricity.

It is also the first airport in the Kingdom to supply 35% sustainable aviation fuel, with the operator stating the blend “reduces the emissions produced by each aircraft… by up to 35%.”

Dubai’s solar build-out

In the UAE, Dubai Airports has begun installing nearly 63,000 solar panels across both DXB and DWC in what it called “the world’s largest rooftop solar installation project at an airport.”

The system, with a capacity of 39 MWp, is expected to generate more than 60,000 MWh annually. Dubai Airports says this will meet 6.5% of DXB’s power demand and 20% of DWC’s needs, cutting 23,000 tonnes of CO₂ a year.

Chief executive Paul Griffiths said the effort is about “embedding sustainability into the core of everything we do,” and reducing the hub’s long-term energy dependency.

The model follows Terminal 2’s earlier 5 MW solar installation, which already reduces the building’s grid electricity use by around 29%.

Car parks as power plants in Abu Dhabi

Abu Dhabi has taken a more decentralised approach. At Zayed International Airport’s new terminal, a solar-powered car park uses 7,542 panels generating 3 MW of capacity.

The installation supplies the parking structure and exports excess power to the terminal, saving around 5,300 tonnes of CO₂ annually.

Abu Dhabi Airports CEO Shareef Al Hashmi said the new terminal was designed with “technology which enables sustainability, protects the environment, and creates a cleaner, greener… building.”

The result is an airport where shaded parking doubles as distributed generation infrastructure.

Saudi Arabia’s off-grid test case

Red Sea International is even more ambitious. The entire airport is designed to operate off the national grid, supported by large-scale solar farms and battery storage.

The wider destination is expected to avoid up to 600,000 tonnes of CO₂-equivalent emissions each year once operational.

The airport’s renewable-first model shows what a new build can achieve when energy is treated as central infrastructure rather than a utility bill.

Airlines push the fuel transition

While airports build electricity capacity, Gulf airlines are tackling the fuel challenge.

Emirates has conducted several high-profile demonstration flights using 100% SAF in one engine, including a Boeing 777-300ER and an A380.

After the first 777 demo flight, Emirates COO Adel Al Redha called it “a milestone moment… and a positive step for our industry,” highlighting the need to cut aviation’s carbon footprint.

Industry-wide, SAF production remains small. IATA estimates global SAF output could reach 2 million tonnes in 2025, still less than 1% of expected airline fuel demand.

That gap illustrates why airports capable of hosting renewable generation, storage and SAF supply will become critical nodes in aviation’s energy transition.

Why the Gulf is positioned to lead

The Gulf has a combination of advantages that few regions can match. Its solar resources rank among the strongest in the world, and both Saudi Arabia and the UAE have government mandates that push renewable deployment at scale.

Many of the region’s flagship megaprojects are being built from scratch, allowing energy systems to be designed around clean power from day one rather than retrofitted later.

Large areas of available land make it feasible to install solar fields, battery storage and district-scale utilities, while airports themselves are increasingly planned as components of integrated city districts rather than stand-alone transport hubs.

Saudi Arabia aims to add 130 gigawatts of renewable capacity by 2030, and the UAE’s Energy Strategy 2050 targets a 50% clean-energy share in the national mix, creating a policy environment in which airport-level generation becomes a natural extension of wider national goals.

At destinations such as Amaala, entire utility networks, from energy and water to cooling, waste and airport systems, are being developed as one unified platform, positioning the airport as an active contributor to a clean-energy ecosystem rather than a passive consumer of power.

Pilot projects and operating models

Most Gulf airports are still early in the journey. Dubai’s rooftop programme and Abu Dhabi’s solar car park cover only part of each hub’s needs. But the direction is unmistakable.

As Abu Dhabi’s leadership put it, “net zero development has been a central ethos” in terminal design, a phrase now repeated across the region.

Red Sea International shows what a fully renewable airport can look like. Dubai shows how the biggest hubs can retrofit at scale.

Together they point to a future in which Gulf airports act not only as passengers’ gateways but as energy producers, storage sites and fuel hubs, infrastructure that powers both the grid and the aircraft it serves.

In the Gulf’s new aviation model, clean energy is a crown jewel.

title: Australia Biofuel Market: Renewable Fuel, Agricultural Feedstock & Low-Carbon Shift | Earth
description:
Australia’s biofuel market is entering a period of strong expansion as demand grows for sustainable, lower-carbon fuel alternatives in transport, industry and energy sectors.
Request a Sample Report with Latest 2026 Edition: What the Opportunities Are The expanding Australia biofuel market offers several distinct opportunities for producers, investors, supply-chain players, agricultural stakeholders, and policy-makers: 1.
Cultivating oilseed crops or collecting and processing used cooking oil/waste fats for biofuel feedstock creates new revenue streams for rural and agricultural communities.
Why Should You Know About Australia Biofuel Market?
In short: the biofuel market is not just about fuel — it’s about energy security, sustainable agriculture, emissions reduction, industrial transformation and long-term value creation.
text:
Australia’s biofuel market is entering a period of strong expansion as demand grows for sustainable, lower-carbon fuel alternatives in transport, industry and energy sectors. The Australia biofuel market size reached USD 2.79 billion in 2024, and is projected to grow to USD 9.29 billion by 2033, reflecting a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 12.8% during 2025–2033.

This growth underscores how biofuels — including biodiesel, bioethanol and emerging advanced biofuels — are becoming central to Australia’s low-carbon fuel strategy, leveraging local feedstocks, regulatory support, and rising environmental awareness.

Why the Market Is Growing So Rapidly

Several key forces are fueling the rapid expansion of the biofuel market in Australia:

Strong Policy Support & Regulatory Mandates for Renewable Fuels

One of the primary drivers is government regulations and blending mandates that require or incentivize the use of bioethanol and biodiesel blends in transport fuels. These mandates create a consistent baseline demand for biofuels, encouraging investment in production capacity and supply infrastructure.

Moreover, national and state-level renewable energy and emissions-reduction targets are pushing stakeholders to adopt cleaner fuel options. This regulatory push helps make biofuels economically viable, even when competing with traditional fossil fuels.

Availability & Diversification of Feedstock — Agricultural Residues, Oilseeds, Waste Oils

Australia benefits from a diverse and abundant feedstock base: oilseeds (such as canola), sugar-based residues, used cooking oil, tallow, and potential non-food crops like Pongamia for advanced biofuels.

Recent efforts to develop renewable feedstock sources — including plantation of biofuel-suitable crops and recycling of waste oils — are helping scale production sustainably, reduce raw-material costs, and strengthen supply security.

Rising Demand for Cleaner Transport & Energy Security

As awareness of climate change grows, consumers, businesses and governments are increasingly open to cleaner, greener energy. Biofuels offer a drop-in alternative to conventional petrol and diesel — usable in existing internal-combustion engines — making transitions easier.

Additionally, for sectors that are harder to electrify (heavy transport, industrial vehicles, aviation, agriculture), biofuels present an immediately deployable low-carbon solution. This demand helps fuel investments and infrastructure expansion for biofuel production and distribution.

Technological Advances & Development of Advanced Biofuels

The biofuel industry in Australia is gradually evolving beyond first-generation bioethanol and biodiesel. There's increasing interest in advanced biofuels — including renewable diesel, waste-to-fuel conversions, and next-gen feedstocks like Pongamia.

New production processes, improved yields, waste-derived feedstock utilisation and sustainability-linked innovations are making biofuels more cost-effective and scalable, attracting greater investment and accelerating adoption.

Request a Sample Report with Latest 2026 Edition:

What the Opportunities Are

The expanding Australia biofuel market offers several distinct opportunities for producers, investors, supply-chain players, agricultural stakeholders, and policy-makers:

1. Scale-up of Biodiesel & Bioethanol Production Capacity

With demand growing, there is room for expanding existing refineries and establishing new plants — especially those leveraging local feedstock (oilseeds, waste oils, agricultural residues). Producers focusing on efficient, sustainable operations can capture significant market share.

2. Advanced & Second-Generation Biofuels Development

Investments into advanced biofuels — using non-food oilseed crops (e.g., Pongamia), waste biomass, or waste oils — offer long-term potential. These fuels, especially renewable diesel or sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), can cater to sectors that are hard to electrify, offering high-margin opportunities.

3. Feedstock Supply Chain & Agricultural Integration

Farmers, agri-commodity companies, waste-oil recyclers and feedstock-suppliers can benefit from increased demand. Cultivating oilseed crops or collecting and processing used cooking oil/waste fats for biofuel feedstock creates new revenue streams for rural and agricultural communities.

4. Infrastructure & Distribution Network Expansion

As demand rises, so does the need for blending, storage, transport, distribution — including refineries, blending terminals, logistics, and fuel-station support. Infrastructure investors and logistics providers have opportunities to build and upgrade networks to support scaled biofuel distribution.

5. Low-Carbon Transport & Heavy-Duty Sector Adoption

Biofuel producers and distributors can target heavy-duty transport, agriculture equipment, marine, aviation and industrial applications — where electrification is difficult and biofuels offer immediate decarbonization.

6. Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) & Export-Ready Biofuel Supply

As global demand for sustainable aviation fuel grows, Australia’s biofuel sector — particularly those producing renewable diesel or SAF-ready feedstock — is well positioned to serve export markets, especially in Asia-Pacific.

Recent News & Developments in Australia Biofuel Market

• June 2025: A new report highlighted that biofuel blending mandates and supportive regulatory reforms have increased investor interest and pipeline projects for biodiesel and ethanol capacity expansion across Australia — reinforcing long-term demand structure.

• August 2025: Several agricultural and energy-sector stakeholders announced pilot programmes cultivating non-food oilseed crops (like Pongamia) for renewable diesel feedstock — marking a shift toward sustainable, locally grown biofuel inputs and reducing reliance on imported oilseeds.

• November 2025: Industry press noted a surge in corporate and transport-fleet uptake of biodiesel blends and interest from heavy-duty haulage companies in converting part of their diesel consumption to biofuel blends — signalling commercial demand growth beyond personal vehicles.

Why Should You Know About Australia Biofuel Market?

You should know about Australia’s biofuel market because it represents a critical lever in the country’s energy transition, environmental strategy, and fuel-sector evolution. As the economy seeks to decarbonize, biofuels offer a practical, scalable alternative — especially for transport and sectors where electrification is challenging.

For producers, biofuel offers a strong growth opportunity across production, feedstock, distribution, and end-use sectors. For investors and supply-chain stakeholders, this market promises growth, diversification, and long-term value — anchored by regulatory support, sustainability demand and expanding adoption. For agriculture and rural economies, biofuels can offer new value for crops, waste oils, residues, and feedstock supply chains, unlocking rural development and circular-economy benefits.

In short: the biofuel market is not just about fuel — it’s about energy security, sustainable agriculture, emissions reduction, industrial transformation and long-term value creation. Understanding it means staying ahead where energy, environment and economy meet.

title: The bioeconomy surrounds us but there is enormous potential for more - Irish Examiner
description:
Meanwhile, our farmers grow our food using bio-fertilisers, our factories produce sustainable packaging with hemp, and our batteries use wood-pulp.
Welcome to the bioeconomy — an innovative solution to a fossil-based problem that we quickly need to leave behind.
In 2023, the EU bioeconomy generated €863 billion, representing 5% of EU GDP and supporting over 17 million jobs.
Ireland has a Bioeconomy Action Plan and the National Development Plan also highlights the sector’s potential.
Europe needs to nurture those bio-based sectors with the greatest potential for economic expansion and environmental benefit.
text:
Meanwhile, our farmers grow our food using bio-fertilisers, our factories produce sustainable packaging with hemp, and our batteries use wood-pulp. Each item and material every bit as effective and reliable as their fossil-based alternatives. Each of them circular and climate-friendly by design.

And what if we could do all that while supporting rural communities, delivering quality jobs and green growth, and reducing our carbon footprint at the same time?

It’s much closer than you might have thought. Welcome to the bioeconomy — an innovative solution to a fossil-based problem that we quickly need to leave behind.

In 2023, the EU bioeconomy generated €863 billion, representing 5% of EU GDP and supporting over 17 million jobs. But it has the potential to be so much more.

The EU is well-positioned to lead the global bioeconomy: powered by science and innovation, based on our own natural resources and raw materials, and supported by our single market.

More than two-thirds of EU member states have committed to national bioeconomy strategies. Ireland has a Bioeconomy Action Plan and the National Development Plan also highlights the sector’s potential. We want to support more breakthroughs to make the leap from innovation to growth.

The EU’s new Bioeconomy Strategy aims to supercharge this growth. We will work with farmers, foresters and other small businesses to bridge the gap from lab to market and turn ideas into industrial reality.

The strategy will ensure a robust financial ecosystem, combining public and private investment. It will also provide regulatory clarity; delivering simple, coherent rules that speed up approvals for innovative solutions.

Europe needs to nurture those bio-based sectors with the greatest potential for economic expansion and environmental benefit. But this growth must be guided by a firm commitment to sustainability.

Europe’s forests, soils and other ecosystems need to be managed wisely, and within ecological limits. We have one eye on green growth and the other on a sustainable future, and that means the bioeconomy must combat biodiversity loss and pollution.

That also requires a strong focus on circularity and better use of leftover biomass like organic waste or agricultural residues such as cereal straw or sawdust. Instead of being dumped, these can fertilise our crops, feed our animals or form the basis for biomaterials. We can turn waste into wealth and help Europe to produce more value with fewer primary resources.

The bioeconomy can boost European prosperity and sharpen our competitive edge. And it will reduce our reliance on vulnerable global supply chains and on other countries for raw materials.

I see it as a defining pillar of the European project to build strategic autonomy and tackle climate change; a society-wide investment in our rural communities and regions, in our environment and ecosystems, and most of all, in our future.

Think about it as you go about your day, surrounded by countless fossil-based products. And imagine a cleaner, more sustainable, more resilient Europe.

title: Orlen SA (PSKOF) Q3 2025 Earnings Call Highlights: Record-Breaking Growth Amidst Strategic ...
description:
Release Date: November 20, 2025 For the complete transcript of the earnings call, please refer to the full earnings call transcript.
Positive Points Orlen SA (PSKOF) reported a record-breaking period with its stock market value doubling and significant investments in offshore wind farms.
Orlen SA (PSKOF) became the seventh largest company on the Norwegian continental shelf in terms of gas production, valued at $2.5 billion.
Orlen SA (PSKOF) reported record-breaking sales in four major markets, with a notable performance in the competitive Czech Republic market.
(Unidentified Company Representative) For the complete transcript of the earnings call, please refer to the full earnings call transcript.
text:
This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

Release Date: November 20, 2025

For the complete transcript of the earnings call, please refer to the full earnings call transcript.

Positive Points

Orlen SA (PSKOF) reported a record-breaking period with its stock market value doubling and significant investments in offshore wind farms.

The company achieved a solid EBITDA of nearly 9 billion PLN, with contributions from all business segments, indicating stability.

Orlen SA (PSKOF) became the seventh largest company on the Norwegian continental shelf in terms of gas production, valued at $2.5 billion.

The company launched an HVO installation at Plock, boosting biofuel production and aligning with European regulations for sustainable aviation fuel.

Orlen SA (PSKOF) reported record-breaking sales in four major markets, with a notable performance in the competitive Czech Republic market.

Negative Points

The company faced challenges with supply and installation services for its offshore wind projects, impacting project timelines.

Petrochemical sales experienced a 16% decline due to the inflow of raw materials from other parts of the world.

Orlen SA (PSKOF) did not meet its CAPEX target for the year, with a shortfall of approximately PLN 2 billion due to lower spending in upstream projects.

The company anticipates lower production capacities in the fourth quarter due to maintenance shutdowns, particularly affecting Mozejki and Czech Republic operations.

Petrochemical margins are expected to remain under pressure, with lower margins anticipated in the upcoming quarter.

Q & A Highlights

Warning! GuruFocus has detected 7 Warning Signs with PSKOF.

Is PSKOF fairly valued? Test your thesis with our free DCF calculator.

Q: What are Orlen's plans for Ukraine in terms of gas and crude oil, and will there be any strategic adjustments or organizational restructuring? A: We are selling gas to Ukraine and preparing to purchase crude from there, though it involves third-party countries like Slovakia and the Czech Republic. The European Union's financing for Ukraine's gas purchases hasn't started yet, but Polish companies are preparing to participate. Our strategy will be reviewed next year, with adjustments expected by mid-2026. Organizational restructuring is ongoing, with procedural barriers being addressed, and we aim to complete this by the first quarter of 2026. (Unidentified Company Representative)

Q: Can you explain the reasons behind the increase in refining margins and the status of agreements with Naftogaz? A: Several factors influence refining margins, including the supply of Russian fuels and the destruction of Ukrainian production units. The agreement with Naftogaz was postponed due to security concerns but will be signed soon. Regarding potential acquisitions of Lukoil assets in Europe, it's too early to comment as we await Lukoil's approach to the process. (Unidentified Company Representative)

Q: What is Orlen's approach to distribution tariffs in electricity, and how might they compare to this year's tariffs? A: Discussions are ongoing, and while I can't provide specifics beyond what the Minister of Energy has stated, energy transition requires expanding and upgrading the distribution network. Any decrease in working capital affects our CapEx projects, and we remain flexible in our approach to regulations. (Maciej Markiewicz, Bloomberg)

Q: Why did Orlen not meet its CapEx target this year, and what is the target for 2026? A: We missed the target by about PLN 2 billion due to lower spending in upstream and the reallocation of projects. The lease of gas carriers also shifted some CapEx to 2026. Our strategy outlines higher ambitions for 2026, so we expect CapEx to increase compared to 2025. (Unidentified Company Representative)

Q: What is the status of the arbitration processes with Venture Global and Gazprom? A: The Venture Global arbitration is ongoing, with a positive outlook following BP's recent success. We expect the first stage of this process to conclude by late 2026. The Gazprom process is complex, involving mutual claims, and details are available on our website. Supplies under the Venture Global contract have started, with full delivery expected by 2027. (Unidentified Company Representative)

For the complete transcript of the earnings call, please refer to the full earnings call transcript.

title: Expander Announces Progress In Biomass Based E-Fuels Project In Mackenzie, British Columbia
description:
The Mackenzie Biofuel Project will become thefirst of kind low carbon clean fuel production in British Columbia andCanada using forestry wood waste biomass (cellulose).
Expander is also very pleased to announce thatcommunity and Indigenous leaders / organizations have provided theirsupport for the MackenzieBiofuel Project.
The McLeod Lake Indian Band(“MLIB”) and the District of Mackenzie (“Mackenzie”) haveprovided letters of support for further development of theproject.
The Mackenzie Biofuel Project is one of the three projects identified in the feasibility studycompleted earlier this year.
Contact Information Expander Energy Inc. Gord N. Crawford, P.Eng.
text:
(TheNewswire)

Calgary, Alberta, Nov 27, 2025 –TheNewswire - Expander Energy Inc. (“Expander”) ispleased to announce that a letter of intent has been signed with EastFraser Fiber Co. Ltd. (“EastFraser”) to secure the required biomassfeedstock and land for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project, a proposed BiomassElectrolysis to Liquids (BETL®) Bio-Synfuel facility in Mackenzie,British Columbia (BC).

BETL is an innovative, patented and patent pendingprocess for making low carbon bio-synthetic fuels developed byCanadian Nuclear Laboratories (CNL) and Expander which leveragesExpander’s technology for biomass gasification, bio-synthetic fuelproduction, and electrolysis technology. The resulting fuel will becomprised entirely of carbon sourced from biogenic (atmospheric)sources and is expected to have very low life cycle carbonintensity.

The proposed facility will utilize the BETL®technology to convert 84,000 dry tonnes per year of forestry woodwaste into 30 million litersper year of renewable diesel, renewable naphthaand bio-wax with life cycle carbon intensity of the fuel to levels80% lower than fossilequivalents (as low as 14 gCO2e/MJ using the BC Low Carbon FuelsBranch (BCLCFS) GHGenius LCA model). The biofuel production isintended to displace fossil derived fuels (e.g., diesel, aviationfuel) and could result in a net avoidance of up to 90,000 tonnes of carbon dioxideannually. The 100km area surrounding Mackenziehas significant fiber resources. Expander will assess the potentialto scale the Mackenzie Biofuel Project to process a total of 336,000tonnes of dry biomass per year to produce 120 million litres per year Bio-Synfuelproduction and net avoidance of 360,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide peryear.

Growing global demand for Sustainable Aviation Fuel(SAF) makes the addition of Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (FT- SPK)production to the facility commercially appealing. Expander iscurrently working with key strategic commercial partners from theaviation industry to assess initial market interest in 18 million liters/year of SAF, with potential opportunity to expand SAF to 72 millionliters/year production. The Mackenzie Biofuel Project will become thefirst of kind low carbon clean fuel production in British Columbia andCanada using forestry wood waste biomass (cellulose). This facility could meet much of the short-term SAF targetfor British Columbia.

Expander is also very pleased to announce thatcommunity and Indigenous leaders / organizations have provided theirsupport for the MackenzieBiofuel Project. The McLeod Lake Indian Band(“MLIB”) and the District of Mackenzie (“Mackenzie”) haveprovided letters of support for further development of theproject.

The Mackenzie Biofuel Project is one of the three projects

identified in the feasibility studycompleted earlier this year. Expander aims to continue the developmentof the project with the goal to secure funding early in 2026, withproduction by 2029. Natural Resources Canada through the Clean FuelsFund program supported the completion of a feasibility study thathelped to identify several prospect locations across Canada, one ofwhich was this Mackenzie site. The Clean Fuels Fund has alsosupported the Front-End Engineering and Design (FEED) study that isexpected to be complete in early 2026 and will result in acomprehensive facility design, cost, schedule and business plan forthe Mackenzie BiofuelProject.

The completed facility will be a global showcase fornext generation biomass based E-fuel production.

“We are thrilled to announce significant progress onthe Mackenzie Biofuels Project. Over the past 18 months, ourdevelopment team has worked tirelessly, and we are on track tocomplete the fully funded $8 million FEED study by Q1 2026. With landand feedstock secured, and strong support from key community andIndigenous leaders, we are now able to accelerate the project.” saidSteve Kresnyak, Executive Vice President and Chief Technology Officer,Expander Energy Inc. “In addition, Expander Energy Inc. is activelyengaging with strategic partners to secure project funding. We lookforward to sharing more details as these partnerships are finalized,marking another step toward delivering price competitive Biomass basedE-fuels for Industry and Aviation”

“It is truly exciting to see the BETL® Bio-Synfuelprocess progress to this stage. Achieving this new supply agreementbrings the technology another step closer towards the production ofeconomical, ready-to-deploy, renewable fuels,” commented Dr. StephenBushby, CNL’s Vice-President of Science and Technology. “Thisproject leverages Canada’s expertise and capabilities in hydrogenand hydrogen isotopes – originally built in support of the nuclearsector, to advance bold, innovative ideas towards deployment. Thisdemonstrates the true spirit of collaboration, working together toovercome challenges and find solutions.”

“East Fraser Fiber sees the production of Biomass based E-fuels as

an important compliment to existing commercial operations in the

Mackenzie BC area, with the potential for additional facilities at

other Parallel Lumber Group facilities in Canada and the USA.” Said

Ante Cirko – Vice President - East Fraser Fiber Co. Ltd.

“The MacLeod Lake Indian Band is

committed to environmentally responsible development of natural

resources within our traditional lands that are consistent with the

values of the Tse’khene people and provide significant economic

opportunities in the region for decades to come.” Said Chief Harley

Chingee – MacLeod Lake Indian Band

“The District of Mackenzie is thrilled to welcome a

Biomass Electrolysis to Liquids Plant to our community. The past few

years have been extremely challenging as residents watched our tax

base shrink and community members suffer job losses. The Mackenzie

Bio-Synfuels facility is a huge step forward in promoting economic

growth for our community and the region. Their advanced proven

technology will also provide additional support to our forest industry

with their utilization of forest harvesting residuals. We are

excited our community will be a participant in this sustainable

solution that will reduce use of fossil fuels, while removing

“wildfire fuels” from the forests surrounding Mackenzie.” said

Mayor Joan Atkinson – District of Mackenzie

About Expander Energy

Inc.

Expander Energy Inc. is a Calgary, Alberta-based energy technology

company that has developed a patented suite of transportation fuel

production technologies to convert biomass, captured carbon and low

Carbon Intensity electricity into “fossil free” low life cycle

carbon intensity synthetic diesel fuel (Bio-SynDiesel®) and synthetic

kerosene jet fuel (Bio-SynJet®). Expander’s Bio-Energy Carbon

Capture and Sequestration (BECCS) solution utilizes cellulosic biomass to produce next

generation low CI synthetic fuels while efficiently capturing

bio-carbon for geologic sequestration. Bio-SynDiesel®,

Bio-SynJet®, BGTL®, EBTL®, BETL®, and CETL® are trademarks of

Expander Energy Inc.

About Canadian Nuclear

Labs

As

Canada’s premier nuclear science and technology laboratory and

working under the direction of Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL),

CNL is a world leader in the development of innovative nuclear science

and technology products and services. Guided by an ambitious corporate

strategy known as Vision 2030, CNL fulfills three strategic priorities

of national importance – restoring and protecting the environment,

advancing clean energy technologies, and contributing to the health of

Canadians. To learn more about CNL, please visit www.cnl.ca

About East Fraser Fiber

Inc.

East

Fraser Fiber Co. Ltd. is a Canadian wood-product manufacturer that

produces finger-joint studs, trim blocks, and wood chips, serving the

North American construction market. Founded in 1990 by the Glazier

brothers, the company is part of the Parallel Lumber Group. For more

information, please see www.plbrg.com

About the McLeod Lake

Indian Band

The

McLeod Lake Indian Band (MLIB) is part of the Tse’khene group of

Aboriginal peoples, including bands at Fort Ware (Kwadacha) and

Ingenika (Tseh Kay Dene). The main community of McLeod Lake Band is

located on McLeod Lake Indian Band Indian Reserves #1 and #5

near the unincorporated

village of McLeod Lake, approximately 150 kilometres north of Prince

George on Highway 97. For more information, please see www.mlib.ca

About the District of

Mackenzie.

The District of Mackenzie is a friendly, planned community of

approximately 3,700 residents in north-central British Columbia, known

for its natural resource-based industries (primarily forestry, mining,

and bio-fuel) and abundant outdoor recreation opportunities. For

more information visit www.districtofmackenzie.ca

Forward Looking Information

This press release contains “forward-looking

information” within the meaning of Canadian securities legislation.

Forward-looking information generally refers to information about an

issuer’s business, capital, or operations that is prospective in

nature, and includes future-oriented financial information about the

issuer’s prospective financial performance or financial

position.

The forward-looking information in this press release

relates to Expander and Rocky Mountains plans to build and operate

Biomass to Liquids facilities.

Expander has made certain material assumptions to

develop the forward-looking information in this presentation,

including assumptions about the availability of financing to build

Biomass to Liquids facilities and the demand for paraffinic synthetic

diesel, jet and naphtha. By its nature,

forward-looking information is subject to various significant risks

and uncertainties, which could cause the actual results and

expectations to differ materially from the anticipated results or

expectations expressed in this news release.

Expander assumes no obligation to update or revise the

forward-looking information in this press release unless it is

required to do so under Canadian securities legislation.

Contact Information

Expander Energy Inc.

Gord

N. Crawford, P.Eng. - President and CEO

1185

– 10201 Southport Road SW Calgary Alberta T2W 4X9

g.crawford@expanderenergy.com 780-966-4673

www.expanderenergy.com

title: Expander Announces Progress In Biomass Based E-Fuels Project In Mackenzie, British Columbia
description:
The Mackenzie Biofuel Project will become the first of kind low carbon clean fuel production in British Columbia and Canada using forestry wood waste biomass (cellulose).
Expander is also very pleased to announce that community and Indigenous leaders / organizations have provided their support for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project.
The McLeod Lake Indian Band (“MLIB”) and the District of Mackenzie (“Mackenzie”) have provided letters of support for further development of the project.
The Mackenzie Biofuel Project is one of the three projects identified in the feasibility study completed earlier this year.
Contact Information Expander Energy Inc. Gord N. Crawford, P.Eng.
text:
Calgary, Alberta, Nov 27, 2025 – TheNewswire - Expander Energy Inc. (“Expander”) is pleased to announce that a letter of intent has been signed with East Fraser Fiber Co. Ltd. (“East Fraser”) to secure the required biomass feedstock and land for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project, a proposed Biomass Electrolysis to Liquids (BETL®) Bio-Synfuel facility in Mackenzie, British Columbia (BC).

BETL is an innovative, patented and patent pending process for making low carbon bio-synthetic fuels developed by Canadian Nuclear Laboratories (CNL) and Expander which leverages Expander’s technology for biomass gasification, bio-synthetic fuel production, and electrolysis technology. The resulting fuel will be comprised entirely of carbon sourced from biogenic (atmospheric) sources and is expected to have very low life cycle carbon intensity.

The proposed facility will utilize the BETL® technology to convert 84,000 dry tonnes per year of forestry wood waste into 30 million liters per year of renewable diesel, renewable naphtha and bio-wax with life cycle carbon intensity of the fuel to levels 80% lower than fossil equivalents (as low as 14 gCO2e/MJ using the BC Low Carbon Fuels Branch (BCLCFS) GHGenius LCA model). The biofuel production is intended to displace fossil derived fuels (e.g., diesel, aviation fuel) and could result in a net avoidance of up to 90,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide annually. The 100km area surrounding Mackenzie has significant fiber resources. Expander will assess the potential to scale the Mackenzie Biofuel Project to process a total of 336,000 tonnes of dry biomass per year to produce 120 million litres per year Bio-Synfuel production and net avoidance of 360,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per year.

Growing global demand for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) makes the addition of Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (FT- SPK) production to the facility commercially appealing. Expander is currently working with key strategic commercial partners from the aviation industry to assess initial market interest in 18 million liters/year of SAF, with potential opportunity to expand SAF to 72 million liters/year production. The Mackenzie Biofuel Project will become the first of kind low carbon clean fuel production in British Columbia and Canada using forestry wood waste biomass (cellulose). This facility could meet much of the short-term SAF target for British Columbia.

Expander is also very pleased to announce that community and Indigenous leaders / organizations have provided their support for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project. The McLeod Lake Indian Band (“MLIB”) and the District of Mackenzie (“Mackenzie”) have provided letters of support for further development of the project.

The Mackenzie Biofuel Project is one of the three projects identified in the feasibility study completed earlier this year. Expander aims to continue the development of the project with the goal to secure funding early in 2026, with production by 2029. Natural Resources Canada through the Clean Fuels Fund program supported the completion of a feasibility study that helped to identify several prospect locations across Canada, one of which was this Mackenzie site. The Clean Fuels Fund has also supported the Front-End Engineering and Design (FEED) study that is expected to be complete in early 2026 and will result in a comprehensive facility design, cost, schedule and business plan for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project.

The completed facility will be a global showcase for next generation biomass based E-fuel production.

“We are thrilled to announce significant progress on the Mackenzie Biofuels Project. Over the past 18 months, our development team has worked tirelessly, and we are on track to complete the fully funded $8 million FEED study by Q1 2026. With land and feedstock secured, and strong support from key community and Indigenous leaders, we are now able to accelerate the project.” said Steve Kresnyak, Executive Vice President and Chief Technology Officer, Expander Energy Inc. “In addition, Expander Energy Inc. is actively engaging with strategic partners to secure project funding. We look forward to sharing more details as these partnerships are finalized, marking another step toward delivering price competitive Biomass based E-fuels for Industry and Aviation”

“It is truly exciting to see the BETL® Bio-Synfuel process progress to this stage. Achieving this new supply agreement brings the technology another step closer towards the production of economical, ready-to-deploy, renewable fuels,” commented Dr. Stephen Bushby, CNL’s Vice-President of Science and Technology. “This project leverages Canada’s expertise and capabilities in hydrogen and hydrogen isotopes – originally built in support of the nuclear sector, to advance bold, innovative ideas towards deployment. This demonstrates the true spirit of collaboration, working together to overcome challenges and find solutions.”

“East Fraser Fiber sees the production of Biomass based E-fuels as an important compliment to existing commercial operations in the Mackenzie BC area, with the potential for additional facilities at other Parallel Lumber Group facilities in Canada and the USA.” Said Ante Cirko – Vice President - East Fraser Fiber Co. Ltd.

“The MacLeod Lake Indian Band is committed to environmentally responsible development of natural resources within our traditional lands that are consistent with the values of the Tse’khene people and provide significant economic opportunities in the region for decades to come.” Said Chief Harley Chingee – MacLeod Lake Indian Band

“The District of Mackenzie is thrilled to welcome a Biomass Electrolysis to Liquids Plant to our community. The past few years have been extremely challenging as residents watched our tax base shrink and community members suffer job losses. The Mackenzie Bio-Synfuels facility is a huge step forward in promoting economic growth for our community and the region. Their advanced proven technology will also provide additional support to our forest industry with their utilization of forest harvesting residuals. We are excited our community will be a participant in this sustainable solution that will reduce use of fossil fuels, while removing “wildfire fuels” from the forests surrounding Mackenzie.” said Mayor Joan Atkinson – District of Mackenzie

About Expander Energy Inc.

Expander Energy Inc. is a Calgary, Alberta-based energy technology company that has developed a patented suite of transportation fuel production technologies to convert biomass, captured carbon and low Carbon Intensity electricity into “fossil free” low life cycle carbon intensity synthetic diesel fuel (Bio-SynDiesel®) and synthetic kerosene jet fuel (Bio-SynJet®). Expander’s Bio-Energy Carbon Capture and Sequestration (BECCS) solution utilizes cellulosic biomass to produce next generation low CI synthetic fuels while efficiently capturing bio-carbon for geologic sequestration. Bio-SynDiesel®, Bio-SynJet®, BGTL®, EBTL®, BETL®, and CETL® are trademarks of Expander Energy Inc.

About Canadian Nuclear Labs

As Canada’s premier nuclear science and technology laboratory and working under the direction of Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL), CNL is a world leader in the development of innovative nuclear science and technology products and services. Guided by an ambitious corporate strategy known as Vision 2030, CNL fulfills three strategic priorities of national importance – restoring and protecting the environment, advancing clean energy technologies, and contributing to the health of Canadians. To learn more about CNL, please visit www.cnl.ca

About East Fraser Fiber Inc.

East Fraser Fiber Co. Ltd. is a Canadian wood-product manufacturer that produces finger-joint studs, trim blocks, and wood chips, serving the North American construction market. Founded in 1990 by the Glazier brothers, the company is part of the Parallel Lumber Group. For more information, please see www.plbrg.com

About the McLeod Lake Indian Band

The McLeod Lake Indian Band (MLIB) is part of the Tse’khene group of Aboriginal peoples, including bands at Fort Ware (Kwadacha) and Ingenika (Tseh Kay Dene). The main community of McLeod Lake Band is located on McLeod Lake Indian Band Indian Reserves #1 and #5 near the unincorporated village of McLeod Lake, approximately 150 kilometres north of Prince George on Highway 97. For more information, please see www.mlib.ca

About the District of Mackenzie.

The District of Mackenzie is a friendly, planned community of approximately 3,700 residents in north-central British Columbia, known for its natural resource-based industries (primarily forestry, mining, and bio-fuel) and abundant outdoor recreation opportunities. For more information visit www.districtofmackenzie.ca
